awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research:  Observed and Future Dynamically Downscaled Estimates of Precipitation Associated with Mesoscale Convective Systems
awd_abstract_narration:
A mesoscale convective system (MCS) is a collection of thunderstorms organized on a larger scale than the storms it contains, in which the individual thunderstorms act in concert to generate the atmospheric motion that organizes and sustains the system.  These large storm systems produce extreme weather including hail, floods, and tornados, but they also make an important contribution to water resources over the eastern two thirds of the continental US (CONUS) during the growing season.  This project seeks to understand MCS behavior in an aggregate sense, including the long-term contribution of MCS precipitation to the overall water balance of the CONUS and the importance of year-to-year variability in MCS activity for anomalously wet (flood) or dry (drought) conditions.  

A key tool for conducting the research is the  Weather Services International (WSI) National Operational Weather radar (NOWrad) data set, a 20-year record (currently 1996-2015) created from the National Weather Service radar stations which provide continuous near-total coverage of the CONUS. A primary goal of the project is to develop and apply an automated procedure to detect and track MCSs in the radar data.  The algorithm identifies MCSs as contiguous or semi-contiguous features in radar maps over an area of at least 100km along the system's major axis exceeding a threshold reflectivity value.  MCS tracking is complicated by the the tendency of MCSs to split and merge as they propagate, and the algorithm incorporates a method for identifying mergers and splits. A further issue is that large regions of intense precipitation can occur in frontal cyclones and landfalling hurricanes, and a classification scheme is necessary to distinguish these regions from MCSs.  A machine learning technique to perform this classification is developed using expert judgement to train a random forest classifier (RFC) scheme. Further expert judgement is solicited through a survey which invites the research community to participate in the development and validation of the tracking and classification schemes.  The catalog of MCS events and their characteristics (intensity, duration, structure, etc) is then used to study MCS seasonality, interannual variability, and contribution to CONUS rainfall including floods and droughts.

Further work uses a global climate model (GFDL-CM3) in combination with a regional convection permitting model (WRF-ARW at 4km horizontal resolution) to simulate MCSs over the CONUS under present-day and projected future climate conditions.  The simulations are analyzed according to the tracking and classification schemes developed for the NOWrad data, and the model simulations allow examination of how MCS behavior depends on climatic factors such as tropospheric moisture, soil moisture, atmospheric stability, and large-scale atmospheric circulation.

The work has broader impacts due to the importance of MCS rainfall as a water resource for agriculture and the severe weather hazards related to MCS activity.  The algorithms and datasets produced for the project will be shared with researchers and operational climatologists and hydrologists through an online portal.  In addition, the project supports and trains a graduate student and provides summer  support for an undergraduate, thereby providing for the future scientific workforce in this area.

por.por_cntn:
This NSF award used the large thunderstorm complex known as a mesoscale convective system, or MCS, as an instrument to assess the small-scale fingerprint of climate change on thunderstorms and their perils while delivering a deeper understanding of short- and long-term hydroclimate variability in the U.S.

Initially, we produced novel, radar-based identification and tracking algorithms to generate long-term climatologies of thunderstorms, establishing the relative hydroclimatological importance of these precipitating systems on the many industries dependent on their water inputs. We also developed new methods to identify and evaluate long-term trends in observed perils from these thunderstorms, including hail, damaging winds, and tornadoes.

After this baseline understanding was established, we generated a novel, high-resolution (horizontal grid spacing of 3.75 km; data output interval of 15-minutes), dynamically downscaled simulation dataset that helps inform regional and local stakeholders regarding potential impacts of climate change on extreme weather events. The regional climate model covered the contiguous U.S., southern Canada, northern Mexico, and adjacent oceans. To examine potential future climate regimes, three 15-year simulation epochs were examined, including a historical (HIST; 1990-2005) and two future (FUTR; 2085-2100) time slices. The FUTR scenario was simulated using Representative Concentration Pathways 4.5 and 8.5 to examine the impact of both intermediate and pessimistic emission scenarios on small-scale extreme weather events. After verification of the HIST data against climatology, we evaluated how a wide variety of storms and perils will change in the 21st century.

Since the project's focus was on the MCS, we presented results on how MCSs and their precipitation will change in the 21st century using these simulation data, with findings suggesting an expected eastward shift in regional MCS activity and precipitation. We also discovered that the character of precipitation in the 21st century will change, with more precipitation coming from MCSs than from non-MCSs, or isolated storms.  Effectively replacing non-MCS precipitation with MCS precipitation may result in fundamentally different hydrologic responses, which may have significant implications for industries affected by water inputs and overall water balance.

Because the simulations generated a treasure trove of weather attributes and perils, we moved beyond the project's primary goal of MCSs to examine a plethora of other sensible weather effects and how climate change may affect their distributions and magnitudes. This included research and resulting papers that examined: snowstorms; particularly intense, long-lived, rotating thunderstorms known as supercells; long-lived, non-tornadic, MCS-driven windstorms known as derechos; short-term extreme precipitation events; significant hail; supercell precipitation; influence of changes in extreme precipitation on debris flows; etc. To date, we have published twelve manuscripts across nine different journals and expect to publish another dozen on aspects related to the data generated from this award in the next year or two.

A corresponding goal was to train the next generation of STEM scientists by developing students with expertise in artificial intelligence, numerical modeling, and other advanced analysis techniques.  The project has resulted in a Ph.D. dissertation and five M.S. theses to date, with current M.S. and Ph.D. students continuing to analyze the hundreds of terabytes of data produced from the simulations. Undergraduate and graduate students affiliated with the project have learned new skill sets related to dealing with "big data", including programming, working with high-performance computing, and artificial intelligence /machine learning (AI/ML). We have used our project's datasets and workflows in several classes, especially those courses related to programming, numerical modeling, and research applications in the atmospheric sciences. We developed SVRIMG, an AI/ML model benchmark dataset and software for classifying storm morphology in weather radar data. It follows FAIR data principles and serves as an educational resource in applied ML/AI learning. We have delivered dozens of talks and/or interviews to the public (STEM events, libraries, etc.), media (AP, NYTimes, CNN, The Weather Channel, National Geographic, etc.), and industry (agriculture groups, insurance and reinsurance conferences, etc.) where we have disseminated results from our efforts. Overall, the project far exceeded its proposed goals and will continue to generate new research findings regarding MCSs and other weather and climate attributes for the foreseeable future.
